frames.core

Class Node

  • java.lang.Object
    • frames.primitives.Frame
      • frames.core.Node
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Grabber
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Shape

    public class Node
extends Frame
implements Grabber
    A Node is a Frame element on a Graph hierarchy, which converts user gestures into translation, rotation and scaling updates (see translationSensitivity(), rotationSensitivity() and scalingSensitivity()). A node may be attached to some of your visual objects to control their behavior using an Agent.

    Geometry transformations

    To define the position, orientation and magnitude of a visual object, use Frame.matrix() (see the Frame class documentation for details) or applyTransformation() (or applyWorldTransformation()), as shown below:

    // Builds a node located at (0,0,0) with an identity orientation (node and world axes match)
    Node node = new Node(graph);
    graph.pushModelView();
    node.applyWorldTransformation(); //same as graph.applyModelView(node.matrix());
    // Draw your object here, in the local coordinate system.
    graph.popModelView();

    Alternatively, the node geometry transformation may be automatically handled by the graph traversal algorithm (see Graph.traverse()), provided that the node visit() method is overridden, as shown below: 

     
 node = new Node(graph) {
   public void visit() {
     //hierarchical culling is optional and disabled by default
     cull(cullingCondition);
     if(!isCulled())
       // Draw your object here, in the local coordinate system.
   }
 }

    Implement a cullingCondition to perform hierarchical culling on the node (culling of the node and its descendants by the Graph.traverse() algorithm). The isCulled() flag is false by default, see cull(boolean).

    A node may also be defined as the Graph.eye() (see isEye() and Graph.setEye(Frame)). Some user gestures are then interpreted in a negated way, respect to non-eye nodes. For instance, with a move-to-the-right user gesture the Graph.eye() has to go to the left, so that the scene seems to move to the right.

    Behaviors

    To implement a node behavior derive from this class and override interact(). For example, with the following code: 
     
 Shortcut left = new Shortcut(PApplet.LEFT);
 Shortcut right = new Shortcut(PApplet.RIGHT);
 node = new Node(graph) {
   public void interact(Event event) {
     if(left.matches(event.shortcut()))
       rotate(event);
     if(right.matches(event.shortcut()))
       translate(event);
   }
 }

    your custom node will then accordingly react to the LEFT and RIGHT mouse buttons, provided it's added to the mouse-agent first (see Agent.addGrabber(Grabber).

    Note that actions are bound to the node using the event Shortcut attribute which identifies it. For instance Shortcut(PApplet.LEFT)) tells us the event is a MotionEvent2 mouse drag.

    Note that a node implements by default several gesture-to-motion converting methods, such as: rotate(Event), moveForward(Event), translateXPos(), etc.

    Picking

    Picking a node is done accordingly to a precision(). Refer to setPrecision(Precision) for details.

      • random

        public static Node random(Graph graph)
        Returns a random graph node. The node is randomly positioned inside the ball defined by center and radius (see Vector.random()). The Frame.orientation() is set by Quaternion.random(). The magnitude is a random in [0,5...2].
        See Also:
        randomize()

      • reference

        public Node reference()
        Description copied from class: Frame
        Returns the reference frame, in which this frame is defined.

        The frame Frame.translation(), Frame.rotation() and Frame.scaling() are defined with respect to the Frame.reference() coordinate system. A null reference frame (default value) means that the frame is defined in the world coordinate system.

        Use Frame.position(), Frame.orientation() and Frame.magnitude() to recursively convert values along the reference frame chain and to get values expressed in the world coordinate system. The values match when the reference frame is null.

        Use Frame.setReference(Frame) to set this value and create a frame hierarchy. Convenient functions allow you to convert coordinates from one frame to another: see Frame.coordinatesOf(Vector), Frame.localCoordinatesOf(Vector) , Frame.coordinatesOfIn(Vector, Frame) and their inverse functions.

        Vectors can also be converted using Frame.transformOf(Vector), Frame.transformOfIn(Vector, Frame), Frame.localTransformOf(Vector) and their inverse functions.

        Overrides:
        reference in class Frame

      • setReference

        public void setReference(Frame frame)
        Description copied from class: Frame
        Sets the Frame.reference() of the frame.

        The frame Frame.translation(), Frame.rotation() and Frame.scaling() are then defined in the Frame.reference() coordinate system.

        Use Frame.position(), Frame.orientation() and Frame.magnitude() to express the frame global transformation in the world coordinate system.

        Using this method, you can create a hierarchy of frames. This hierarchy needs to be a tree, which root is the world coordinate system (i.e., null Frame.reference()). No action is performed if setting reference as the Frame.reference() would create a loop in the hierarchy.

        Overrides:
        setReference in class Frame

      • setReference

      • children

        public java.util.List<Node> children()
        Returns a list of the node children, i.e., nodes which reference() is this.

      • visit

        public void visit()
        Procedure called on the node by the graph traversal algorithm. Default implementation is empty, i.e., it is meant to be implemented by derived classes.

        Hierarchical culling, i.e., culling of the node and its children, should be decided here. Set the culling flag with cull(boolean) according to your culling condition: 

         
 node = new Node(graph) {
   public void visit() {
     //hierarchical culling is optional and disabled by default
     cull(cullingCondition);
     if(!isCulled())
       // Draw your object here, in the local coordinate system.
   }
 }
        See Also:
        Graph.traverse(), cull(boolean), isCulled()

      • cull

        public void cull()
        Same as cull(true).
        See Also:
        cull(boolean), isCulled()

      • cull

        public void cull(boolean cull)
        Enables or disables visit() of this node and its children during Graph.traverse(). Culling should be decided within visit().
        See Also:
        isCulled()

      • isCulled

        public boolean isCulled()
        Returns whether or not the node culled or not. Culled nodes (and their children) will not be visited by the Graph.traverse() algoruthm.
        See Also:
        cull(boolean)

      • applyTransformation

        public void applyTransformation(Graph graph)
        Convenience function that simply calls graph.applyTransformation(this). You may apply the transformation represented by this node to any graph you want using this method.

        Very efficient prefer always this than

        See Also:
        applyTransformation(), Frame.matrix(), Graph.applyTransformation(Frame)

        See Also:
        applyWorldTransformation(), Frame.worldMatrix(), Graph.applyWorldTransformation(Frame)

      • damping

        public float damping()
        Defines the spinning deceleration.

        Default value is 0.5. Use setDamping(float) to tune this value. A higher value will make damping more difficult (a value of 1 forbids damping).

      • setDamping

        public void setDamping(float damping)
        Defines the damping(). Values must be in the range [0..1].

      • rotationSensitivity

        public float rotationSensitivity()
        Returns the influence of a gesture displacement on the node rotation.

        Default value is 1 (for instance matching an identical mouse displacement), a higher value will generate a larger rotation (and inversely for lower values). A 0 value will forbid rotation (see also Frame.constraint()).

        See Also:
        setRotationSensitivity(float), translationSensitivity(), scalingSensitivity(), keySensitivity(), spinningSensitivity(), wheelSensitivity()

      • scalingSensitivity

        public float scalingSensitivity()
        Returns the influence of a gesture displacement on the node scaling.

        Default value is 1, a higher value will generate a larger scaling (and inversely for lower values). A 0 value will forbid scaling (see also Frame.constraint()).

        See Also:
        setScalingSensitivity(float), setRotationSensitivity(float), translationSensitivity(), keySensitivity(), spinningSensitivity(), wheelSensitivity()

      • translationSensitivity

        public float translationSensitivity()
        Returns the influence of a gesture displacement on the node translation.

        Default value is 1 which in the case of a mouse interaction makes the node precisely stays under the mouse cursor.

        With an identical gesture displacement, a higher value will generate a larger translation (and inversely for lower values). A 0 value will forbid translation (see also Frame.constraint()).

        See Also:
        setTranslationSensitivity(float), rotationSensitivity(), scalingSensitivity(), keySensitivity(), spinningSensitivity(), wheelSensitivity()

      • spinningSensitivity

        public float spinningSensitivity()
        Returns the minimum gesture speed required to make the node spin. Continuously spinning requires to set damping() to 0.

        Gesture speed is expressed in pixels per milliseconds. Default value is 0.3 (300 pixels per second). Use setSpinningSensitivity(float) to tune this value. A higher value will make spinning more difficult (a value of 100 forbids spinning in practice).

        See Also:
        setSpinningSensitivity(float), translationSensitivity(), rotationSensitivity(), scalingSensitivity(), keySensitivity(), wheelSensitivity(), setDamping(float)

      • wheelSensitivity

        public float wheelSensitivity()
        Returns the wheel sensitivity.

        Default value is 15. A higher value will make the wheel action more efficient (usually meaning faster motion). Use a negative value to invert the operation direction.

        See Also:
        setWheelSensitivity(float), translationSensitivity(), rotationSensitivity(), scalingSensitivity(), keySensitivity(), spinningSensitivity()

      • keySensitivity

        public float keySensitivity()
        Returns the keyboard sensitivity.

        Default value is 10. A higher value will make the keyboard more efficient (usually meaning faster motion).

        See Also:
        setKeySensitivity(float), translationSensitivity(), rotationSensitivity(), scalingSensitivity(), wheelSensitivity(), setDamping(float)

      • isSpinning

        public boolean isSpinning()
        Returns true when the node is spinning. Spinning is started by user interaction, e.g., rotate(Event).
        See Also:
        isFlying(), stopSpinning()

      • stopSpinning

        public void stopSpinning()
        Stops the spinning motion. Spinning is started by user interaction, e.g., rotate(Event). Note that isSpinning() will return false after this call. Attention: Spinning may be decelerated according to damping() till it stops completely.
        See Also:
        damping()

      • spin

        public void spin(Quaternion quaternion)
        Rotates the node using quaternion around its Frame.position() (non-eye nodes) or around the Graph.anchor() when this node is the Graph.eye(). Called by a timer when the node isSpinning().
        See Also:
        damping()

      • align

        public void align()
        Wrapper method for Frame.alignWithFrame(Frame, boolean, float) that discriminates between eye and non-eye nodes.
        See Also:
        isEye()

      • center

        public void center()
        Centers the node into the graph.

        Same as return screenToVector(new Vector(x, y, z)).

      • screenToVector

        public Vector screenToVector(Vector vector)
        Same as return eyeToReferenceFrame(screenToEye(vector)). Transforms the vector from screen (device) coordinates to reference() coordinates.
        See Also:
        screenToEye(Vector), eyeToReferenceFrame(Vector)

      • eyeToReferenceFrame

        public Vector eyeToReferenceFrame(float x,
                                  float y,
                                  float z)
        Same as return eyeToReferenceFrame(new Vector(x, y, z)).
        See Also:
        eyeToReferenceFrame(Vector)

      • eyeToReferenceFrame

        public Vector eyeToReferenceFrame(Vector vector)
        Converts the vector from eye coordinates to reference() coordinates.

        It's worth noting that all gesture to node motion converting methods, are implemented from just screenToEye(Vector), eyeToReferenceFrame(Vector) and screenToQuaternion(float, float, float).

        See Also:
        screenToEye(Vector), screenToQuaternion(float, float, float)

      • screenToEye

        public Vector screenToEye(float x,
                          float y,
                          float z)
        Same as return screenToEye(new Vector(x, y, z)).
        See Also:
        screenToEye(Vector)

      • screenToEye

        public Vector screenToEye(Vector vector)
        Converts the vector from screen (device) coordinates into eye coordinates.

        It's worth noting that all gesture to node motion converting methods, are implemented from just screenToEye(Vector), eyeToReferenceFrame(Vector) and screenToQuaternion(float, float, float).

        See Also:
        eyeToReferenceFrame(Vector), screenToQuaternion(float, float, float)

      • screenToQuaternion

        public Quaternion screenToQuaternion(Vector angles)
        Same as return screenToQuaternion(angles.vec[0], angles.vec[1], angles.vec[2]).
        See Also:
        screenToQuaternion(float, float, float)

      • screenToQuaternion

        public Quaternion screenToQuaternion(float roll,
                                     float pitch,
                                     float yaw)
        Reduces the screen (device) Extrinsic rotation into a Quaternion.

        It's worth noting that all gesture to node motion converting methods, are implemented from just screenToEye(Vector), eyeToReferenceFrame(Vector) and screenToQuaternion(float, float, float).

        Parameters:
        roll - Rotation angle in radians around the screen x-Axis
        pitch - Rotation angle in radians around the screen y-Axis
        yaw - Rotation angle in radians around the screen z-Axis
        See Also:
        Quaternion.fromEulerAngles(float, float, float)

      • isFlying

        public boolean isFlying()
        Returns true when the node is flying.

        When flying, damping() translates the node by its fly direction at a frequency defined when the node _fly(Vector, MotionEvent).

        Use _fly(Vector, MotionEvent) and stopFlying() to change this state. Default value is false.

        isSpinning()

      • stopFlying

        public void stopFlying()
        Stops the flying motion started using _fly(Vector, MotionEvent). isFlying() will return false after this call. Attention: This method may be called by damping(), since flying may be decelerated according to damping() till it stops completely.
        See Also:
        damping(), stopSpinning()

      • flySpeed

        public float flySpeed()
        Returns the fly speed, expressed in graph units.

        It corresponds to the incremental displacement that is periodically applied to the node by _moveForward(MotionEvent, boolean). Attention: When the node is set as the Graph.eye(), this value is set according to the Graph.radius() by Graph.setRadius(float).

      • setFlySpeed

        public void setFlySpeed(float speed)
        Sets the flySpeed(), defined in graph units.

        Default value is 0.01f * graph().radius().

      • precisionThreshold

        public float precisionThreshold()
        Returns the picking precision threshold in pixels used by the node to track(Event).
        See Also:
        setPrecisionThreshold(float)

      • precision

        public Node.Precision precision()
        Returns the node picking precision. See setPrecision(Precision) for details.
        See Also:
        setPrecision(Precision), setPrecisionThreshold(float)

      • setPrecision

        public void setPrecision(Node.Precision precision)
        Sets the node picking precision.

        When precision() is Node.Precision.FIXED or Node.Precision.ADAPTIVE Picking is done by checking if the pointer lies within a squared area around the node center() screen projection which size is defined by setPrecisionThreshold(float).

        When precision() is Node.Precision.EXACT, picking is done in a precise manner according to the projected pixels of the visual representation related to the node. It is meant to be implemented by derived classes (providing the means attach a visual representation to the node) and requires the graph to implement a back buffer.

        Default implementation of this policy will behave like Node.Precision.FIXED.

        See Also:
        precision(), setPrecisionThreshold(float)

      • setPrecisionThreshold

        public void setPrecisionThreshold(float threshold)
        Sets the length of the squared area around the node center() screen projection that defined the track(Event) condition used for node picking.

        If precision() is Node.Precision.FIXED, the threshold is expressed in pixels and directly defines the fixed length of a 'shooter target', centered at the projection of the node origin onto the screen.

        If precision() is Node.Precision.ADAPTIVE, the threshold is expressed in object space (world units) and defines the edge length of a squared bounding box that leads to an adaptive length of a 'shooter target', centered at the projection of the node origin onto the screen. Use this version only if you have a good idea of the bounding box size of the object you are attaching to the node shape.

        The value is meaningless when the precision() is* Node.Precision.EXACT. See setPrecision(Precision) for details.

        Default behavior is to set the precisionThreshold() (in a non-adaptive manner) to 20.

        Negative threshold values are silently ignored.

        See Also:
        precision(), precisionThreshold(), track(Event)

      • grabsInput

        public boolean grabsInput(Agent agent)
        Check if this node is the Agent.inputGrabber(). Returns true if this object grabs the agent and false otherwise.

      • grabsInput

        public boolean grabsInput()
        Checks if the node grabs input from any agent registered at the graph input-handler.
